de.esoco.lib.app

Class Application

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.obrel.core.RelatedObject
      • de.esoco.lib.app.Application
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.obrel.core.Relatable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ModificationSyncServiceTool, Service

    public abstract class Application
extends org.obrel.core.RelatedObject
    Base class for applications. A subclass must at least implement the method runApp() and a main method that invokes the run(String[]) method on an instance of the application. It may also override any of the other runtime methods (and it should normally also invoke super in them). The runtime methods are invoked in the following order:
    1. processArguments(String[]): evaluates the command line
    2. initialize(CommandLine): initialization of app parameters
    3. configure(CommandLine): configuration of the application
    4. startApp():
    5. runApp():
    6. stopApp(): invokes the following two methods:
      1. cleanup(): performs a cleanup of registered resources
      2. terminate(): terminates the application

    • Constructor Summary

      Application()
      Default constructor.

      • run

        public final void run(java.lang.String[] rArgs)
        This method must be invoked on new instances. It will perform the default steps necessary to initialize and run the application.
        Parameters:
        rArgs - The command line arguments of the application

      • runApp

        protected abstract void runApp()
                        throws java.lang.Exception
        This is the main method that must be implemented by all subclasses. It contains the code the will perform the applications actual work task(s). The implementation may throw exceptions to signal errors but it must be aware that this will skip any final application method invocations. If final cleanup tasks need to be run anyway the implementation should do so in the method handleApplicationError(Exception), e.g. by invoking the cleanup() method.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • addManagedResource

        protected void addManagedResource(java.lang.Object rResource)
        Allows to add a resource to be managed by this application. Such resources must implement at least one of the management interfaces Stoppable, Closeable, or Disposable. They may also implement the RunCheck interface in which case the cleanup code will wait for the shutdown of the resource after stopping it. This is checked by an assertion. Attention: Subclasses must invoke the super implementation of cleanup() method to make this mechanism work.

        The management interface will be processed in the order in which they are mentioned above. First all Stoppable objects will be stopped. Then it will be waited until all RunCheck instances have terminated (or until an application specific timeout has been reached). Finally, all closeable objects will be closed and then all disposable objects will be disposed.

        On cleanup the registered resources will be released in the reverse order of registration. That means that the first registered resource will be released first and vice versa. This allows to register resources that have (one-way) dependencies on each other.

        Parameters:
        rResource - The resource, implementing some management interfaces

      • cleanup

        protected void cleanup()
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Performs the cleanup of all resources that have been registered with addManagedResource(Object). This method will be invoked by stopApp().

        Subclasses may override this method to perform additional cleanup of resources that have been allocated by the application if necessary. But they should always invoke super.cleanup() in their implementation. The order of this invocation depends on the subclass. It is recommended to first release all access to registered resources, then invoke super.cleanup() and finally free all subclass resources on which registered resources did depend.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • configure

        protected void configure(CommandLine rCommandLine)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        May be overridden by subclasses to configure the application. Will be invoked directly after the method initialize(CommandLine). Subclasses should always invoke super as the first step in their implementation.
        Parameters:
        rCommandLine - The parsed command line of the application
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • displayUsageError

        protected void displayUsageError(CommandLineException e)
        Displays information about a usage error of this application. The default implementation displays an error message if a command line exception is provided and then invokes printUsage(PrintStream).
        Parameters:
        e - An optional command line exception that indicates a usage error or NULL for none

      • getAppDescription

        protected java.lang.String getAppDescription()
        Returns a description of this application. If present it will be displayed together with the usage string that is output by the method printUsage(PrintStream). The default implementation returns NULL.
        Returns:
        The application description

      • getCommandLineOptions

        protected java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> getCommandLineOptions()
        Can be overridden by subclasses to provide a mapping from allowed command line options to corresponding help text string. The default implementation returns an empty map to indicate that arbitrary options are allowed. See the documentation of class CommandLine for more information.
        Returns:
        A mapping from allowed command line options to help texts

      • getNameOfAppBinary

        protected java.lang.String getNameOfAppBinary()
        Returns the name of the distribution binary of this application (typically a JAR file).
        Returns:
        The name of the application binary if available

      • handleApplicationError

        protected void handleApplicationError(java.lang.Exception e)
        This method can be overridden by applications to handle errors that have been signaled by exceptions from one of the runtime methods of this instance. The default implementation only logs the error.
        Parameters:
        e - The exception that signaled the error

      • initialize

        protected void initialize(CommandLine rCommandLine)
                   throws java.lang.Exception
        May be overridden by subclasses to initialize the application. This is the first method that will be invoked by the run(String[]) method. Subclasses should always invoke super as the first step in their implementation.
        Parameters:
        rCommandLine - The parsed command line of the application
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • isShutdownRequested

        protected boolean isShutdownRequested()
        Checks whether a shutdown of the application has been requested. Applications should check this flag in their processing loop and cleanup and terminate as soon as possible if this method returns TRUE.
        Returns:
        TRUE if a shutdown has been requested

      • printHelp

        protected void printHelp(java.lang.Object rCommand)
        Prints help for this application or for a single command.
        Parameters:
        rCommand - The optional command

      • printUsage

        protected void printUsage(java.io.PrintStream rOutput)
        Prints information about how to use this application. Should be overridden by subclasses that need complex arguments to work.
        Parameters:
        rOutput - The output stream

      • processArguments

        protected CommandLine processArguments(java.lang.String[] rArgs)
                                throws java.lang.Exception
        Processes the application's command line arguments and returns them in a command line object.
        Parameters:
        rArgs - The application arguments
        Returns:
        A command line instance containing the parsed arguments
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • removeManagedResource

        protected void removeManagedResource(java.lang.Object rResource)
        Removes a managed resource that has previously been added by invoking addManagedResource(Object) without performing the regular resource cleanup that is done by the cleanup() method.
        Parameters:
        rResource - rOld The resource object to be remove

      • requestShutdown

        protected void requestShutdown()
        Will be invoked from a separate thread if a shutdown of the application has been requested.

      • startApp

        protected void startApp()
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        May be overridden by subclasses to perform the tasks necessary to start the application. This can be used to run code that must be run before or parallel with the actual application code (e.g. additional threads). Will be invoked after the method configure(CommandLine) and just before the method runApp(). Subclasses should always invoke super as the first step in their implementation.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • stopApp

        protected void stopApp()
                throws java.lang.Exception
        May be overridden by subclasses to perform the tasks necessary to prepare the termination of the application. An example would be to stop threads that have been run in parallel with the main application code. Will be invoked after the method runApp() has finished.

        The default implementation invokes the methods cleanup() and terminate() in that order. Therefore subclasses should either invoke the super method to perform the final application cleanup or implement the corresponding handling by themselves.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • terminate

        protected void terminate()
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        May be overridden by subclasses to execute the final termination of the application if necessary (e.g. invoke System.exit() with a specific error code). Will be invoked as the last method in stopApp(). The default implementation does not exit the application. Subclasses should invoke super.terminate() as the last call in their implementation to keep base class functionality like logging but this is not mandatory.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Subclasses may throw exceptions to signal errors

      • waitForResource

        protected int waitForResource(RunCheck rResource,
                              int nMaxWaitTime,
                              int nSleepTime)
        Cleanup helper method that lets the current thread wait for a certain resource to stop execution. The resource must implement the RunCheck interface to be processed by this method.
        Parameters:
        rResource - The resource to wait for
        nMaxWaitTime - The maximum time to wait for this resource
        nSleepTime - The time to wait between checks of the resource
        Returns:
        The time the method has actually waited for the given resource
